item.title: UFO (disambiguation)
item.description:
UFO (disambiguation) ðŸ”—

This page serves as a disambiguation for the term “UFO,” which primarily refers to an unidentified flying object, an aerial phenomenon that cannot be immediately identified or explained. However, “UFO” is also used in various other contexts.

Computer Technology ðŸ”—

This section lists various uses of “UFO” in the realm of computer technology. It includes:

  • .ufo: The file extension for Ulead PhotoImpact documents.
  • Unified File and Object (UFO): An object storage architecture.
  • UHF Follow-On satellite: A series of US military communications satellites.
  • Unified Font Object: An XML-based open format for digital fonts.
  • Unified Foundational Ontology: An upper ontology for conceptual modeling.

Art, Entertainment and Media ðŸ”—

This section covers the diverse applications of “UFO” in art, entertainment, and media, broken down into film and television, music, and video games.

Film and Television ðŸ”—

This subsection lists several films and television series with “UFO” in their titles:

  • UFO (1956 film): Directed by Winston Jones.
  • U.F.O. (1993 film): Starring Roy “Chubby” Brown.
  • U.F.O. (2012 film): Featuring Jean-Claude Van Damme.
  • UFO (2018 film): Directed by Ryan Eslinger, starring Alex Sharp and Gillian Anderson, focusing on an airport sighting.
  • UFO (2022 film): A Turkish Netflix film.
  • UFO (American TV series): A 2021 television documentary by J.J. Abrams.
  • UFO (British TV series): A 1970s TV series by Gerry Anderson.
  • UFOs (TV series): A 2021 French TV series.
  • UFO Ultramaiden Valkyrie: A 2000s manga and anime television series.

Music ðŸ”—

This subsection is further divided into bands and performers, albums, and songs.

Bands and Performers ðŸ”—

This section lists musical artists and groups using “UFO” in their names:

  • UFO (musician): A Danish hip hop artist, rapper, and singer (born 1981).
  • Ufo361: A German rapper (born 1988).
  • UFO (band): An English hard rock band.
  • UFO: The original name of the English R&B group better known as JLS.
  • UFO Yepha: A Danish hip hop duo.
  • The Unidentified Flying Objects: An American rock band.
  • United Future Organization: A Japanese jazz duo.

Albums ðŸ”—

This section lists albums titled “UFO”:

  • U.F.O. (album): A 1969 album by Jim Sullivan.
  • UFO EP: By Torch.
  • UFO (Newton Faulkner EP): By Newton Faulkner.

Songs ðŸ”—

This section lists songs titled “UFO”:

  • “UFO” (Mallrat song featuring Allday): (2018)
  • “UFO” (Pink Lady song): (1977)
  • “UFO”: A song by ESG on their EP ESG (1981).
  • “UFO” (Sneaky Sound System song): (2007)
  • “U.F.O.” (Coldplay song): (2011)
  • “UFO” (Vigiland song): (2014)
  • “U.F.O.”: A song by Blonde Redhead on their album La Mia Vita Violenta (1995).
  • “UFO”: A song by D-Block Europe and Aitch from the album The Blue Print: Us vs. Them (2020).

Other Musical Works ðŸ”—

  • UFO (Michael Daugherty composition): A musical composition.
  • UFOetry: A multimedia UFO rock opera.

Video Games ðŸ”—

This section lists video games with “UFO” in their titles, including the UFO Defense family of games and other unrelated titles.

UFO Defense Family ðŸ”—

  • UFO: Enemy Unknown (1994): Also known as X-COM: UFO Defense.
  • UFO: Aftermath (2003)
  • UFO: Aftershock (2005)
  • UFO: Afterlight (2007)
  • UFO: Alien Invasion (2003)

Other Video Games ðŸ”—

  • UFO (1989): By Sublogic.
  • UFO Kamen Yakisoban (1994): For Super Famicom.
  • U.F.O.s (1997): An adventure game by Artech.
  • UFO: A Day in the Life (1999): By Love-de-Lic.
  • UFO: Extraterrestrials (2007): By Chaos Concept.
  • Undefined Fantastic Object (2009): The twelfth entry in the Touhou Project series by ZUN.

Other Works ðŸ”—

  • UFOs: The Greatest Stories: A 1996 short-story anthology by Martin H. Greenberg.

Games and Sports ðŸ”—

  • Claw vending machine: Also known as UFO.
  • UFO: A style of delivery in Ten-pin bowling.

Clubs ðŸ”—

This section lists clubs with “UFO” in their names:

  • Ufo (Club, Berlin): An Acid House club.
  • UFO Club: A London underground club.

Products and Services ðŸ”—

This section lists products and services branded with “UFO”:

  • UFO: A brand of instant yakisoba.
  • UFO (restaurant): A restaurant in Slovakia.
  • UFO (ride): An amusement park ride.

Other Uses ðŸ”—

This section lists other miscellaneous uses of the acronym “UFO”:

  • United Farmers of Ontario: A Canadian political party c. 1920s.
  • UFO: A variant of float b-boy move.
  • Ufo (wasp): A genus of wasps.
  • UFO 34 (yacht): A sailboat.
  • UFO Radio: A radio station in Taiwan.
  • Uranium Fluorine Oxygen: Representing the chemical elements.
  • Ultra Fast Outflows: Winds that come from supermassive black holes.
  • University of French Ontario: Referring to the UniversitÃ© de l’Ontario franÃ§ais.

See Also ðŸ”—

This section provides links to related disambiguation pages and topics:

  • U-Foes: A Marvel Comics supervillain team.
  • Unidentified flying object (disambiguation)
  • Flying saucer (disambiguation)
  • Alien (disambiguation)

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_(disambiguation)

item.title: Alien (Britney Spears song)
item.description:
Alien (Britney Spears song) ðŸ”—

“Alien” is a song by Britney Spears from her 2013 album Britney Jean. The song is a mid-tempo dance-pop track about Spears’ feelings of loneliness. It received positive reviews from music critics, who praised its production and personal nature. Despite not being released as a single, it charted on the US Bubbling Under Hot 100 and the French Singles Chart. Spears performed the song during her “Britney: Piece of Me” residency.

Background ðŸ”—

After her time as a judge on The X Factor, Spears began working on her eighth studio album in December 2012. William Orbit was announced as a producer for the project in May 2013. Spears described “Alien,” her collaboration with Orbit, as “really cool” and “really great.” There were initial rumors of a collaboration with Lady Gaga, but this did not happen. A demo version of the song leaked online before the album’s release, which Orbit stated had incorrect chorus notes that were fixed in the final version. Spears considered releasing “Alien” as a single, as revealed in her documentary I Am Britney Jean, but this never materialized. In July 2014, an unedited vocal track of Spears singing the song leaked, drawing criticism for her uncorrected vocals. Orbit defended Spears, stating that the leaked audio was a vocal warm-up and not intended for public release.

Composition ðŸ”—

“Alien” is a midtempo dance-pop song co-written by Spears, William Orbit, Dan Traynor, Ana Diaz, and Anthony Preston, and produced by Orbit and HyGrade. The song’s musical style has been compared to Madonna’s Ray of Light album, which was also produced by Orbit. Lyrically, the song explores themes of loneliness. A vocal glitch at 2:14 in the song sparked discussion, with Orbit joking that it was due to an alien abduction.

Critical Reception ðŸ”—

“Alien” was generally well-received by music critics, who praised its production and personal themes. Critics highlighted Orbit’s production and Spears’ vulnerability on the track. Some reviewers compared the song favorably to Madonna’s work with Orbit. However, one critic felt that Spears’ vocal performance did not match the song’s solemn production.

Live Performances ðŸ”—

Spears performed “Alien” during her “Britney: Piece of Me” residency at Planet Hollywood Las Vegas. One performance was notable because Spears was caught lip-syncing when the backing track continued playing after she missed her cue. The song was later removed from the setlist but was briefly re-added following Spears’ breakup with her boyfriend David Lucado.

Credits and Personnel ðŸ”—

Lists the people involved in the creation of the song, including:

  • Songwriters: Britney Spears, William Orbit, Dan Traynor, Ana Diaz, Anthony Preston
  • Producers: William Orbit, HyGrade
  • Engineers: Alan O’Connell, Alan Tilston, John Hanes, Serban Ghenea
  • Additional Vocals: Ana Diaz

The recording took place at Guerrilla Studios in London and was mixed at MixStar Studios in Virginia Beach, Virginia.

Charts ðŸ”—

“Alien” charted on the French Singles Chart and the US Billboard Bubbling Under Hot 100 chart. It reached number 147 in France and number 8 on the Bubbling Under Hot 100 in the US. It also charted in South Korea, reaching number 90 on the Gaon Music Chart.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_(Britney_Spears_song)

item.title: List of songs about close encounters with aliens
item.description:
List of Songs About Close Encounters with Aliens ðŸ”—

This is a compilation of songs across various decades that explore lyrical themes related to close encounters with extraterrestrial aliens.

1940s ðŸ”—

This section highlights the earliest example on the list, “(When You See) Those Flying Saucers” by The Buchanan Brothers, released in July 1947. Its release coincided with the beginning of the flying saucer era, shortly after the Kenneth Arnold UFO sighting.

1950s ðŸ”—

The 1950s saw a surge in songs about flying saucers and aliens. Notable entries include “The Flying Saucer Parts 1 & 2” by Bill Buchanan and Dickie Goodman, “My Flying Saucer” with lyrics by Woodie Guthrie, “The Purple People Eater” by Sheb Wooley, “Two Little Men In A Flying Saucer” by Ella Fitzgerald, and “Flyin’ Saucers Rock & Roll” by Billy Lee Riley and Jerry Lee Lewis.

1960s ðŸ”—

This section lists songs from the 1960s that touch on extraterrestrial themes. Key songs include “Let There Be More Light” and “Set the Controls for the Heart of the Sun” by Pink Floyd, “Mr. Spaceman” by The Byrds, “Voices Green and Purple” by The Bees, “It Came Out of the Sky” by Creedence Clearwater Revival, “Have You Seen the Saucers” by Jefferson Airplane, and “U.F.O.” by Jim Sullivan.

1970s ðŸ”—

The 1970s brought a diverse range of songs exploring alien encounters. Highlights include “After the Gold Rush” by Neil Young, “Calling Occupants of Interplanetary Craft” by Klaatu (covered by The Carpenters), “Childhood’s End” by Pink Floyd, “Come Sail Away” by Styx, “Here Come the Martian Martians” by Jonathan Richman and the Modern Lovers, “Horsell Commons and the Heat Ray” by Jeff Wayne, “I’ve Seen the Saucers” by Elton John, “Longer Boats” by Cat Stevens, “Martian Boogie” by Brownsville Station, “Mothership Connection” by Parliament, “Starman” by David Bowie, “Starship Trooper” and “Arriving UFO” by Yes, “Waiting for the UFOs” by Graham Parker, “Silver Lights” by Sammy Hagar, “UFO” by Johnny Rivers, “Children of the Sun” by Billy Thorpe, “Starrider” by Foreigner, “Strange Ships” by Fox, and “Ships in the Sky” by Wishbone Ash.

1980s ðŸ”—

This section covers songs from the 1980s with alien or UFO themes. Noteworthy songs include “Fire Of Unknown Origin” by Blue Ã–yster Cult, “Books about UFOs” by HÃ¼sker DÃ¼, “Flying Saucers” by Nina Hagen, “Love Walks In” by Van Halen, “Loving the Alien” by David Bowie, “No Doubt About It” by Hot Chocolate, “Nobody Told Me” by John Lennon, “Rapture” by Blondie, “Zero Zero UFO” by The Ramones, “I Ran (So Far Away)” by A Flock of Seagulls, “Caught in the Crossfire” by April Wine, and “Don’t Be Late” by Saga.

1990s ðŸ”—

The 1990s entries include “The Alien Song (For Those Who Listen)” by Mila Jovovich, “El Aparato (“The Apparatus”)” by CafÃ© Tacvba, “Alien (I Am)” by Hawkwind, “Aliens Exist” by Blink-182, “Alien Visitors” by Man or Astro-man?, “Another Sunday” by I Mother Earth, “Fell in Love with an Alien” by the Kelly Family, “Hangar 18” by Megadeth, “Hat Too Flat” by Walter Becker, “I Made Love to a Martian” by Mustard Plug, “Girl from Mars” by Ash, “Martian Dance Invasion” by Brainiac, “Motorway to Roswell” by Pixies, “Scent of a Mule” by Phish, “Shades of Grey” by Stuart Davis, “Spaceman” by Babylon Zoo, “Subterranean Homesick Alien” by Radiohead, “The Happening” by Pixies, “Who’s There?” by Smash Mouth, “Spaceman” by Bif Naked, “Is That You Mo-Dean?” by The B-52s, “Men in Black” by Will Smith, and “Calgone” by Incubus.

2000s to present ðŸ”—

This section lists songs from the 2000s to the present day. It includes “Fracture” by Edison’s Children (Neil Armstrong’s son’s band), “The Aliens Are Here” by The Hippos, “And You Thought the Doctor’s Probe Hurt” by Belvedere, “Jaadoo, Jaadoo” by Rajesh Roshan, “Concerning the UFO sighting near Highland, Illinois” by Sufjan Stevens, “Aliens” by Doctor Octagon, “UFO” by Sneaky Sound System, “Rosetta Stoned” by Tool, “Fallout of the 4th Kind” by Edison’s Children, “We’re Not Alone” by Nas, “Spaceman” by The Killers, “Venus Ambassador” by Bryan Scary & The Shredding Tears, “E.T.” by Katy Perry featuring Kanye West, “Zopilotes” by CafÃ© Tacuba, “A Million Miles Away (I Wish I Had A Time Machine)” and “The Awakening” by Edison’s Children, “Ancient Aliens” by Lemon Demon, “Decks Dark” by Radiohead, “Hey Aliens” by The Bouncing Souls, “Spaceship” by Kesha, “Herd Culling” by Porcupine Tree, “Silver Circles” by Upchurch, “End of the World” by Tom MacDonald, “Staring at the Stars” by Dan Marfisi and Glenn Jordan, “An Alien Abduction Story (The Probing)” by The Schnooks, and “Down Bad” by Taylor Swift.

Notes ðŸ”—

This section provides a note indicating that certain songs are used as bumper music on the StarTalk podcast UFO episode.

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the various sources used to compile the list of songs, including articles from publications like The A.V. Club, Huffington Post, NPR, Salon.com, New York Times, and books on UFOs and alien encounters.

Further reading ðŸ”—

This section suggests a book for further exploration of the topic: Alien Rock: The Rock ’n’ Roll Extraterrestrial Connection by M. Luckman.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/(When_You_See)_Those_Flying_Saucers

item.title: Aliens Exist
item.description:
Aliens Exist ðŸ”—

“Aliens Exist” is a song by the American rock band Blink-182, featured on their 1999 album Enema of the State. The song, primarily written by guitarist Tom DeLonge with additional credit to bassist Mark Hoppus, is a lighthearted take on the existence of extraterrestrial life. It references UFO phenomena, including alleged CIA involvement and the Majestic 12.

Background ðŸ”—

Blink-182, originating from suburban San Diego, gained prominence in the late 1990s with their pop-punk sound. The band members included guitarist Tom DeLonge, bassist Mark Hoppus, and drummer Travis Barker. DeLonge’s fascination with extraterrestrials began in middle school and continued as he toured, reading books about paranormal activity. Barker recalls DeLonge constantly searching for UFOs. DeLonge used his first personal computer to research alien phenomena. He amassed a collection of UFO books and military interviews about UFO experiences. Hoppus found DeLonge’s beliefs amusing. DeLonge and Hoppus often debated the song’s subject matter, leaving each other messages on their equipment. Barker, then a touring musician, arranged the song’s tempo and structure.

Composition ðŸ”—

The song is written in common time with a tempo of 216 beats per minute, in the key of B major. The lyrics, written by DeLonge, express youthful curiosity about the universe and attempt to convince listeners of the legitimacy of his claims. The lyrics suggest the CIA is suppressing information and reference the Majestic 12, a supposed group of scientists studying alien spacecraft in the 1940s. DeLonge explained the song’s perspective as that of someone who believes in aliens but is dismissed by others, directing his frustration towards the government.

Release and Reception ðŸ”—

“Aliens Exist” was initially previewed as part of an online medley and officially released on Enema of the State in June 1999. It received positive reviews, with some critics praising its departure from typical pop-punk themes.

Live Performances ðŸ”—

Although not released as a single, the band performed the song on The Tonight Show with Jay Leno in 2000. It was a regular part of their tour and live album, The Mark, Tom and Travis Show. The band retired the song in 2002 but revived it on their 2019 tour, with Matt Skiba filling in for DeLonge. DeLonge also performed the song with Angels & Airwaves in 2019. Following DeLonge’s return to Blink-182, the band continued to perform the song on their 2023 world tour, incorporating tabloid imagery of DeLonge’s interest in aliens.

Legacy ðŸ”—

The song has been re-examined in light of DeLonge’s continued pursuit of UFO research. It is remembered as a standout track from Enema of the State and is considered part of American pop culture’s fascination with aliens. Blink-182 embraced this image, using alien imagery on merchandise and at concerts. DeLonge continued to explore alien themes in his band Angels & Airwaves. Machine Gun Kelly’s “Concert for Aliens” was seen as reminiscent of DeLonge’s earlier work. DeLonge co-founded To the Stars, a company focused on aerospace, science, and entertainment, with former government and intelligence officials. In 2017, the company released leaked military footage of unidentified aerial phenomena, later confirmed by the Pentagon, which legitimized DeLonge’s research. This led to the Pentagon formally establishing interest in studying UFOs.

Personnel ðŸ”—

  • Locations:

    • Signature Sound, Studio West (San Diego, California)
    • Mad Hatter Studios, The Bomb Factory (Los Angeles, California)
    • Conway Recording Studios (Hollywood, California)
    • Big Fish Studios (Encinitas, California)

  • Blink-182:

    • Mark Hoppus â€“ bass guitar, vocals
    • Tom DeLonge â€“ guitars, vocals
    • Travis Barker â€“ drums, percussion

  • Production:

    • Jerry Finn â€“ production
    • Tom Lord-Alge â€“ mixing engineer
    • Sean O’Dwyer â€“ recording engineer
    • Darrel Harvey â€“ assistant engineer
    • John Nelson â€“ assistant engineer
    • Robert Read â€“ assistant engineer
    • Mike Fasano â€“ drum technician
    • Brian Gardner â€“ mastering engineer

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aliens_Exist
